Reading through the threads here, it appears the primary question posed is what would hapen in the event of a stablecoin de-pegging, regardless of which stable coin that may be. The secondary question is how Yield APP manages assets. To answer the second question first, please read the most recent pinned message in this group, this was published yesterday and provides detailed information relating to our portfolio activities. For the first question, this is an industry wide systemic risk rather than a Yield App centric risk. The asset backing of any stablecoin is the responsibility of the issuer, the value of the peg or exchange face value itself is determined by market forces and the holders of the those assets. If a stablecoin can be exchanged at a discount or premium to par, this is determined by supply/demand and the macro economic and regulatory thematic at the time should a de-pegging occur. As with any asset or foreign currency, these will always be subject to volatility whether it is a micro standard deviation or more significant change in basis. Users of Yield App will always be able to drawdown the base asset they deposited regardless of its value of exchange such as the ETH dollar value being higher or lower than at the point of depositing the asset. All investments carry a degree of risk, this includes classic cars, NFT's, fine wines, P2P lending etc. which is how a risk premium (user interest rate) is generated compared with asets held in a bank for example. With regard to our honesty, please research us online, through our website FAQ's, LinkedIn, the multitude or educational articles we publish and other publicly available sources. I am personally the Co-chair for the DeFi working group at Global Digital Fiance, the global crytpo regulatory advocacy body and as a Co-founder of Yield App, I would like to reassure you that our users safety and preservation of your capital is our primary focus and concern. Neither myself nor our team can offer you advise only recommend that you research thoroughly any investment regardless of the offerer according to your own needs and satisfaction and make an informed decisions that is suitable for you thereafter. I hope this provides some of the answers you were seeking.

messages.text: üí™üèº

I sincerely thank you for your lengthy and well worded response.
To be frank, I have no doubts regarding your honesty and continued desire to be honest combined with offering the best possible service to your clients, but think about Enron or Lehman Brothers.... I am sure, and I say this with the upmost respect, the Co-Chair or their respective working groups were probably also honest and respectable people. However, events can sometimes unfold in a way that force you to go back on what you originally said. For example, you said that you would like to reassure all customers (I really dislike the word USERS) that the safety and preservation of their capital is your primary focus. Well, Lehman said the same thing, but many people lost a lot of money because the reality of the matter was that the safety and preservation of their clients capital was NOT their primary focus, greed was their primary focus! I am not saying that this is the case with your company, quite the opposite. I have invested with you in the past and I had a very positive experience. However, when bad things happen in markets, and I sincerely hope they do not happen to anyone or any company within the crypto industry, but if they do (and they have in the past), you might be forced, even against your better instincts, to react in a different way than you have put forth in your message. You yourself will likely not know, with certainty, how you will react should a disastrous situation be forced upon you. None of us know that about ourselves until the event happens! Can you honestly say that you have never been dishonest with yourself? Can anyone say that they have never been dishonest with themselves?

I wish you the very best of luck with you endeavour, but please  keep in mind that none of us know how we will react when a major damaging event transpires. We can think it through all we want. We can have endless policy documents to create the illusion of near absolute safety for our clients. We can advertise on expensive sites and have offices that impress even the wealthiest of us. In the end one can just hope that one is dealing with trustworthy people, but one will never truly know that unless put to the test. God day to you, sir! üòä
For this reason, I chose to go Trust-less as much as possible!

    -Insurance statements
